article.title: Ambergris
article.paragraph: other usesFile:Ambergris.jpgthumbupright=1.3AmbergrisAmbergris(IPAc-enˈæmbərgriːsorIPAc-enˈæmbərgrIs,lang-laAmbra grisea,Ambre gris,ambergreaseorgrey amber) is a solid, waxy, flammable substance of a dull grey or blackish colour produced in the digestive system ofsperm whales.cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/18871/ambergrisAmbergrisBritannica31 January 2013The word amber is derived from the Arabic word 'anbar'().Cupboard love 2: A dictionary of cullinary curiosities. Mark Morton.

Freshly produced ambergris has a marine,fecesfaecalodour. However, as it ages, it acquires a sweet, earthy scent commonly likened to the fragrance ofIsopropyl alcoholrubbing alcoholwithout the vaporous chemical astringency.cite bookBurr, ChandlerThe Emperor of Scent: A Story of Perfume, Obsession, and the Last Mystery of the Senses2003New YorkRandom House978-0-375-50797-7Although ambergris was formerly highly valued byperfumersas a fixative (allowing the scent to last much longer), It has now largely been replaced by syntheticambroxan.
article.heading: Sources
article.paragraph: Ambergris occurs as abiliarybile ductsecretion of theintestinesof the sperm whale and can be found floating upon the sea, or lying on the coast. It is also sometimes found in theabdomensofwhales. Because the beaks ofgiant squidshave been found embedded within lumps of ambergris, scientists have theorised that the substance is produced by the whale's gastrointestinal tract to ease the passage of hard, sharp objects that the whale might have eaten. The sperm whale usually vomits these, but if one travels further down the gut, it will be covered in ambergris.cite webhttp://press.uchicago.edu/books/excerpt/2012/kemp_floating.htmlThe Origin of AmbergrisYouTube-ChivtjDjh4

Ambergris is usually passed in the fecal matter. It is speculated that an ambergris mass too large to be passed through the intestines is expelled via the mouth, leading to the reputation of ambergris as primarily coming from whale vomit.cite bookWilliam F. Perrin, Bernd Wursig, J. G.M. ThewissenEncyclopedia of Marine Mammals2009Academic Press008091993628It takes years for ambergris to form. Christopher Kemp, the author ofFloating Gold: A Natural (and Unnatural) History of Ambergris, says that It is only produced by sperm whales, and only by an estimated one percent of them. Once expelled by a whale, it must float for years, then it must make landfall, avoid being broken into pieces by rough seas, and someone must find it.cite bookKempChristopherFloating Gold: A Natural (and Unnatural) History of Ambergrishttp://books.google.com/books?id2012University of Chicago Press978-0-226-43036-2[https://books.google.com.ph/books?idIn other words, the odds of finding ambergris are extremely small. The very small chance of finding ambergris and the legal ambiguity involved led perfume makers away from ambergris.citation neededMay 2015

Ambergris can be found in theAtlantic Oceanand on the coasts ofSouth Africa,Brazil,Madagascar, theEast Indies,The Maldives,China,Japan,India,Australia,New Zealand, and theMaluku IslandsMolucca Islands. In rarer cases, it can be found in other locations. Most commercially collected ambergris comes from theBahamasin theCaribbean, particularlyNew Providence. Fossilised ambergris from 1.75 million years ago has also been found.cite journalBaldanzaAngelaRobertoBizzarriFedericoFamianiPaoloMonacoRobertoPellegrinoPaolaSassiEnigmatic, biogenically induced structures in Pleistocene marine deposits: A first record of fossil ambergrisGeology4110107530 July 201310.1130/G34731.1http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/early/2013/07/30/G34731.12013Geo....41.1075B

A 1.1 kg (2.4 lb) piece of ambergris found on a beach atAnglesey,Wales, was sold for 11,000 at an auction inMacclesfield, UK, on 25 September 2015 to a French buyer.Ambergris found on Anglesey beach sells for 11,000BBC25 September 2015
article.heading: Physical properties
article.paragraph: Ambergris is found in lumps of various shapes and sizes, usually weighing from 15 g (~ oz) to 50 kg (110 pounds), sometimes more. When initially expelled by or removed from the whale, the fatty precursor of ambergris is pale white in colour (sometimes streaked with black), soft, with a strong fecal smell. Following months to years ofphotodegradationandoxidationin the ocean, this precursor gradually hardens, developing a dark grey or black colour, a crusty and waxy texture, and a peculiar odour that is at once sweet, earthy, marine, and animalic. Its smell has been generally described as a vastly richer and smoother version ofisopropanolwithout its stinging harshness. In this developed condition, ambergris has aspecific gravityranging from 0.780 to 0.926. It melts at about 62 C to a fatty, yellow resinous liquid; and atconvert100C0onit is volatilised into a white vapour. It is soluble indiethyl etherether, and in volatile and fixed oils.
article.heading: Chemical properties
article.paragraph: Ambergris is relatively nonreactive to acid. White crystals of aterpeneknown asambreincan be separated from ambergris by heating raw ambergris in alcohol, then allowing the resulting solution to cool. Breakdown of the relatively scentless ambrein through oxidation producesambroxanand ambrinol, the main odor components of ambergris.

Ambroxanis now produced synthetically and used extensively in the perfume industry.cite webhttp://perfumeshrine.blogspot.co.uk/2010/11/ambroxambroxan-modern-fascination-on.htmlAmbrox/Ambroxan: a Modern Fascination on an Elegant Material5 November 2010Perfume Shrine31 January 2013
article.heading: Applications
article.paragraph: Ambergris has been mostly known for its use in creating perfume and fragrance much likemusk. Perfumes can still be found with ambergris around the world.cite webhttp://www.businessweek.com/magazine/ambergris-treasure-of-the-deep-01122012.htmlAmbergris, Treasure of the DeepJanuary 12, 2012EricSpitznagelBloomberg Businessweek31 January 2013It is collected from remains found at sea and on beaches, although its precursor originates from the sperm whale, which is a vulnerable species.cite webhttp://www.iucnredlist.org/apps/redlist/details/41755/0Physeter macrocephalusInternational Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources31 January 2013

Ancient Egyptiansburned ambergris as incense, while in modernEgyptambergris is used for scenting cigarettes.cite bookAmbergrisMaterials Handbook: An Encyclopedia for Managers, Technical Professionals, Purchasing and Production Managers, Technicians, and Supervisors64BradyGeorge StuartClauserHenry R.VaccariJohn A.978-0-07-136076-02002McGraw-HillTheHistory of China#Ancient Chinaancient Chinesecalled the substance "dragon's spittle fragrance".cite webhttp://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?idStrange but True: Whale Waste Is Extremely ValuableApril 26, 2007CynthiaGraberScientific American31 January 2013During theBlack DeathinEurope, people believed that carrying a ball of ambergris could help prevent them from getting the plague. This was because the fragrance covered the smell of the air which was believed to be aMiasma theory of diseasecause of plague.

This substance has also been used historically as aflavoringfor food and is considered anaphrodisiacin some cultures.During theMiddle Ages, Europeans used ambergris as aPharmaceutical drugmedicationforheadaches,Common coldcolds,epilepsy, and other ailments.
article.heading: Legality
article.paragraph: MainInternational Whaling Commission#1986 moratoriumFrom the 18th to the mid 19th century, the whaling industry prospered. By some reports, nearly 5,000 whales, including sperm whales, were killed each year. Due to studies showing that the whale populations were being threatened, the International Whaling Commission instituted a moratorium on commercial whaling in 1986. Although ambergris is not harvested from whales, many countries also ban the trade of ambergris as part of the more general ban on the hunting and exploitation of whales.

Urine, faeces and ambergris (that has been naturally excreted by a sperm whale) are waste products not considered parts or derivatives of a CITES species and are therefore not covered by the provisions of the Convention.CITES CoP16 Com. II Rec. 2 (Rev. 1), Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, Sixteenth meeting of the Conference of the Parties Bangkok (Thailand), 314 March 2013Summary record of the second session of Committee II

list.listitem: Australia Under federal law, the export and import of ambergris for commercial purposes is banned by theEnvironment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. The various States and Territories have additional laws regarding ambergris.cite webhttp://www.environment.gov.au/coasts/species/cetaceans/education/ambergris.htmlWhale and Dolphin permits - AmbergrisEnvironment.gov.au1979-06-282014-03-13

United States The possession and trade of ambergris is prohibited by theEndangered Species Actof 1973.cite webhttp://www.businessweek.com/magazine/ambergris-treasure-of-the-deep-01122012.html#p2Ambergris, Treasure of the DeepBusinessweek2012-01-122014-03-13

article.heading: In culture
article.paragraph: A serving of eggs and ambergris was reportedly KingCharles II of England's favorite dish.cite book[[Thomas Babington Macaulay, 1st Baron Macaulay|Lord Macaulay]]The History of England from the Accession of James II1848Harperhttp://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/14681IV222

In chapter 91 ofHerman Melville'sMoby-Dick(1851), Stubb, one of the mates of thePequod (Moby-Dick)Pequod,fools the captain of a French whaler (Rose-bud) into abandoning the corpse of a sperm whale found floating in the sea. His plan is to recover the corpse himself in hopes that it contains ambergris. His hope proves well founded, and thePequod's crew recovers a valuable quantity of the substance.s:Moby-Dick/Chapter 91''Moby-Dick'', Chapter 91atWikisource.Melville devotes the following chapter to a discussion of ambergris, with special attention to the irony that "fine ladies and gentlemen should regale themselves with an essence found in the inglorious bowels of a sick whale."s:Moby-Dick/Chapter 92''Moby-Dick'', Chapter 92atWikisource.

In the 2001 filmHannibal (film)Hannibal,Hannibal Lectersends Clarice Starling a letter which he writes while intentionally wearing a hand lotion containing ambergris, correctly assuming that this would lead her to discover his location inFlorence, Italy, due to lotion utilizing ambergris being legal in only a few countries.

Ambergris plays a prominent role in the plot of the 2003Futuramaepisode "Three Hundred Big Boys."cite webhttp://theinfosphere.org/Three_Hundred_Big_Boys#Act_III:_.22The_loot.21_The_loot.21.21_The_loot_is_on_fire.21.21.22Three Hundred Big Boys - The Infosphere, the Futurama WikiTheinfosphere.org2014-03-13The episode guest-starsRoseanne Barr, who appears as a hologram of herself, reading the dictionary definition of "ambergris."cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0584461/?ref_Futurama: Season 5, Episode 11 : Three Hundred Big Boys (15 June 2003)IMDb.com2014-03-13

The 1969 bookThe Lost Ones (novel)The Lost Onesby Ian Cameron, later made into Disney's 1974 filmThe Island at the Top of the Worlddepicts a dirigible trip to the 'Whale Graveyard' where they find so much ambergris that it becomes a point of contention.

In the 1956 episode "Whale Gold" of the British television seriesThe Buccaneers (TV series)The Buccaneers, a crew of eighteenth-century pirates led by Captain Dan Tempest (actorRobert Shaw (British actor)Robert Shaw) find large pieces of ambergris at sea and on a beach, discoveries that lead to quarrels and death due to "whale gold fever."
The plot ofThe Avengers (TV series)The Avengers1963 episodeKiller Whale (The Avengers)Killer Whalerevolves around an ambergris smuggling operation.

In the 2014 episode "Ambergris (Bob's Burgers)Ambergris" of the television programBob's Burgers, a lump of ambergris found on the beach plays an important role, as Louise, Tina, and Gene attempt to sell the ambergris illegally for $30,000.

In "Sinbad the Sailor#The Sixth Voyage of Sinbad the SailorThe Sixth Voyage of Sinbad the Sailor" in "The Arabian Nights" byRichard Francis BurtonSir Richard Burton, Sinbad finds vast quantities of Ambergris after being shipwrecked on an unknown island after setting sail fromBasraBassorh.

In "A Romance of Perfume Lands or the Search for Capt. Jacob Cole", F. S. Clifford, October 1881, the last chapter concerns one of the novel's characters discovering an area off of remote island which contains large amounts of ambergris. He hopes to use this knowledge to help make his fortune in the manufacture of perfumes.
